name: NewYorker
text: Alexander Chee recounts the agony and the ecstasy of rose gardening: “I never had the urge to kill a thing until I started growing roses.” https://t.co/3imi1TXmyW

name: NewYorker
text: Joe Biden’s choice for Vice-President is not an ideological commitment but a thematic one, @benwallacewells writes—to the civil-rights tradition and to its politics. https://t.co/NOMhtnQWTz

name: NewYorker
text: The critical window for contract tracing is about five days. Yet after a coronavirus outbreak was tied to a Georgia private school, many families were reluctant to coöperate with the health department. https://t.co/8nLaXzeGkJ

text: Revisit fiction by Zadie Smith, Jennifer Egan, and Stephen King, from the #NewYorkerArchive. https://t.co/gx9MmaP7oF

text:
“I feel bad for young reporters who have to work solitary," JoAnne Wasserman said. "I learned so much from watching and listening.”

name: NewYorker
text: Critics and defenders alike tend to accept Henry Kissinger’s self-mythology, but his record shows a more mundane ﬁgure who assimilated prevailing foreign-policy assumptions. https://t.co/QdBt9axQyr

name: NewYorker
text: In January, Nneka Ogwumike helped negotiate a historic agreement for the W.N.B.A.'s players' union. A couple of months later, she played a central role in deciding how to start the season during a pandemic. On the first night, she didn't miss a shot. https://t.co/sAyc885ANH

name: NewYorker
text: Linda Ronstadt, who left an indelible mark on the classic-rock era, reflects on her career: “It was best when I forgot about everything and just thought about the music.” https://t.co/f8Lpxr1sdU

name: NewYorker
text: The technical transition to wind energy is relatively simple, @BillMcKibben writes, but the cultural transition may take a while. https://t.co/wjEzS7RKoU

name: NewYorker
text: On #NewYorkerRadio, the journalist and historian @Isabelwilkerson talks with David Remnick about how America’s racial hierarchy should be thought of as a caste system, not unlike the one that dominated in India. https://t.co/R9qGSqrzyl

name: NewYorker
text:
Almost precisely a year after assuring skittish voters that “nothing would fundamentally change” if he was elected, Joe Biden said that America was due for “some revolutionary institutional changes.” Read @eosnos’s Profile of the Presidential hopeful.
https://t.co/qOF1GtXMVD

name: NewYorker
text:
Struggling communities need treatment and care and the resources to recover from decades of racism and institutional neglect, @KeeangaYamahtta writes—not more policing.
https://t.co/HeoIvdpEif

name: NewYorker
text: How Jack Ely’s incomprehensible vocal on “Louie Louie” spawned an F.B.I. obscenity investigation, and turned the song into a subversive rock-and-roll anthem. https://t.co/KF1IFX5obS

name: NewYorker
text: “What I love that fiction can do is the way it can get inside a consciousness and the way it can push mystery.” Tommy Orange reads and discusses a story by Louise Erdrich. https://t.co/vKRiIdyHis

name: NewYorker
text: Are pangolins—creatures virtually incapable of harming another animal, and perhaps the most heavily trafficked wild mammals in the world—the source of COVID-19? https://t.co/6TvdpQuUzo
